results.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert Adam Whitely / Felicia JollyGoodFellow (Guy Pearce) costume
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: While most of the Oscar-winning costumes in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert (1994) were made with small budgets and creative solutions, the pom-poms on this iconic wattle dress were made by inmates at the Long Bay Correctional Complex.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

results.title: Edison Home Kinetoscope
results.credit_line: Lent by the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Sydney. Gift of Mrs Dorothy Fawcett, 1997.
results.brief_description: By 1912, advancements in projection allowed the Edison Home Kinetoscope to cast the irregular 22mm film stock in homes.

results.title: Kinora
results.credit_line: Lent by the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Sydney. Purchased 1963.
results.brief_description: In 1896, the Lumière brothers came up with the Kinora, a smaller cinematic device that worked like a mutoscope and flickered through 40-second stories.
results.description: Kinora, cast iron/glass, B.M. & Biograph Co., London, 1870-1899
description_for_label: Kinora, cast iron/glass, B.M. & Biograph Co., London, 1870-1899

results.title: EEE Motor Zoom 8
results.brief_description:
Canon EEE Motor Zoom 8 with leather Canon carry case, booklets, film, lens cleaning tissue and accessories.

From Canon museum website: “The performance of batteries improved significantly around 1959, and batteries with stable performance became available in the market. At the same time, Canon was developing a micro-motor. This is how development of a movie camera with better operability, the core feature of these cameras, started. Instead of a conventional spring motor, it applied an electric motor that could drive film continuously much longer than a spring motor, fully using battery capability. Zooming was performed electrically, as was exposure control, which was called EE, or Electric Eye (AE, or Automatic Exposure today). These were major factors for a very compact movie camera design. Because of its three electric functions, it was named the “EEE”.

The lens was a newly developed 4x f/1.7 zoom lens. Aperture control with two outside levers made EE, manual exposure and fading operation easy. A film rewind crank was applied at the same time. As a result, this camera became suitable for both beginners and advanced amateurs”
